therealbadindian: The probs us Guyanese women face when having to explain our heritage and cultural background I too am of Guyanese East Indian heritage maybe 80% of my family is Hindu people constantly question when I choose to celebrate that side of my heritage and culture eventho my family openly celebrates and acknowledges that part of my heritage smh people need to read more.
marykay_maduike: I personally think people misuse the words “culture appropriation” a lot. It’s the inappropriate adoption of a society’s customs. For one there’s a difference between inappropriately adopting a culture and appreciating a culture. I see no reason why a person of one culture can’t learn and showcase another culture. This is the beauty of diversity and the intersectionality of life. I was born in Nigeria, grew up in several other countries. I adopted their culture and even learnt to speak their language. I self-taught myself the Hindi language. It doesn’t mean I’m not acknowledging the importance of authenticity and the sacredness of certain customs. As a Nigerian there are certain things considered to be an “us” thing, but we all need to understand that teaching others our culture can only lead to a more knowledgeable and equitable world. One can’t comprehend, value and appreciate what they don’t know. 🌍

shradha_bhatia: My thoughts on this: whether you are Indian or not (and yes, I know you are 😁), you’re wearing the lehenga respectfully and on the occasion it is supposed to be worn for - so as an Indian, I don’t really seen the problem! tirsatalks: Some thoughts on what you said in the end of the vid about who benefits from the policing of cultural appropriation, if the alternative was for you to buy a white owned dress. I think you may want to look into the difference between cultural appropriaton and cultural assimilation to get the answer to the question: who benefits. The fact that everybody is allowed to wear white people's culture is because everyone is forced to wear white people's clothing. That's assimilation. Not showing parts of yourself because it will make your life, career etc harder. Many things that are appropriated such as hairstyles, cultural wear etc. would mot be accepted e.g. in the workplace or are banned in schools or the military when people from that culture wear it. This benefits white supremacy. Now, if a white artist wears another culture's heritage or white kids wear it at festivals they are firstly most likely unaware of its origins, and if it went hella mainstream and they got the item from HM, no non-white people benefited from it financially. Finally, if it concerns an artist who wears sth for a performance or video clip, without cultural awareness or proper execution/context, but they make hella money from joining the trend, which poc arent able/allowed to join in on... This is how cultural appropriation benefits white supremacy, by erasing poc history, taking away financial opportunities from poc and making a profit for white people. Your case doesn't include many of these elements, not only are you of the culture you portray, you also know the proper way to contextualize the clothing. + You purchased and promoted a POC owned vendor. Now, I don't think the policing of cultural appropriation is benefitting white supremacy, it is aiming to protect and uplift poc and their cultures. In your case it just seemed like it benefits white supremacy because it was a wrongful accusation. When a white artist wears a bastardized native head dress, or when white girls wear glitter on their forehead without knowing where this custom came from, I don't think this benefits people of colors financial wellbeing or their social status. thank you for coming to my ted talk. ✌🏾

lovelealyds: In the Caribbean, their are few things we would call cultural appropriation. It has to be blatantly wrong and so out of place for us to see it. Living in Trinidad I watch from afar as major western countries deal with that issue. It’s fascinating, in my melting pot of a country where on one street you could have six different ethnicities each with their own cultural practices living on your street as your neighbour. It’s hard for me to grasp it. But if I lived outside that norm, where your culture maybe put down in society but then picked back up by others for “fashion” I think I can emphasize and get it. However, I also need those persons to understand that it’s not a one size fits all, outside of your bubble what you wore is pretty normal. In fact with so many East Indians in Trinidad it’s hard to go a Hindu wedding and not wear a sari or other East Indian wear whether you Indian, African, mixed etc. So I wish ppl would understand one size doesn’t fit all. Cultural appropriation in your world is actually cultural appreciation in mine. Also, you and Jared looked stunning and happy with your love ones and on your wedding day that’s all that matters. ❤
